postsData.name:
Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor
Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor
postsData.content:
𝗪𝗵𝘆 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗱𝗲𝗺𝗼𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗶𝗿 𝘁𝗲𝗮𝗺𝘀?

It's not always what they do, but what they don’t do.

The silent actions that often go unnoticed can significantly impact team morale.

Here’s what many leaders are getting wrong:

1️⃣ Ignoring Struggles
Leaders often assume their team will ask for help if needed.
But the truth? Many struggle silently, feeling unsupported and disengaged.

2️⃣ Holding Back Praise
Thinking “they already know” their value?
You’re missing the mark.
Everyone needs recognition, and without it, doubts start to creep in.

3️⃣ Avoiding Tough Conversations
Leaders avoid discomfort, letting small issues fester.
But addressing problems early prevents bigger issues down the line.

4️⃣ Failing to Lead by Example
Saying “Do as I say, not as I do” doesn’t work.
Teams mirror the behaviors they see, not the instructions they’re given.

Leadership isn’t about grand gestures.

It’s built in the small moments,
the quiet interactions,
the tough conversations,
and the simple act of showing up for your team every day.

Your leadership matters in the little things. Make them count.

What would you add?

Found this helpful?
𝗥𝗲𝗽𝗼𝘀𝘁 to share with your network. ️
Followfor more insights on Leadership and Startup Growth. ️

comments.commentText:
Bonus #2 Failing to Listen Actively
It’s easy to hear words, but true leadership means listening between the lines.
When leaders dismiss ideas or rush conversations, they unknowingly silence innovation and disengage their team.
comments.userName: Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor

comments.commentText:
Bonus #1 Overloading Without Clarity
Leaders assume their team knows what’s most important, but without clear priorities, everything feels urgent.
The result? Burnout, frustration, and wasted effort on the wrong tasks.
comments.userName: Damesha Craig, Leadership Coach and Startup Advisor

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Its the small, consistent actions that truly shape team dynamics. Leadership is indeed in the details! 🌟 #LeadershipMatters

postsData.name:
Michael Walker Ed.D.
Michael Walker Ed.D.
postsData.content:
𝗛𝗼𝘄 𝗶𝘀 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻-𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝘄𝗵𝗲𝗻 𝗶𝘁'𝘀 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝘃𝘀. 𝘄𝗵𝗲𝗻 𝘆𝗼𝘂'𝗿𝗲 𝗼𝗻 𝗮 𝘁𝗲𝗮𝗺?

Just like breathing, we make decisions every day. But does repetition alone make us better at it?

Decision-making is a skill that can be developed, improved, and refined.

The mistake? 𝗪𝗲 𝗮𝘀𝘀𝘂𝗺𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝘃𝗶𝗱𝘂𝗮𝗹𝘀 𝗮𝗹𝘀𝗼 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗸𝘀 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗲𝗮𝗺𝘀.

𝗦𝗼𝗹𝗼 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻-𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 is relatively straightforward:
𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗯𝗹𝗲𝗺 → 𝗢𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 → 𝗗𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻

𝗧𝗲𝗮𝗺 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻-𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴? That’s a whole different process.

It requires:
 𝗦𝗵𝗮𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 (Are we aligned on what we know?)
 𝗦𝘂𝗿𝗳𝗮𝗰𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮𝘀𝘀𝘂𝗺𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 (What biases are shaping our thinking?)
 𝗙𝗿𝗮𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗿𝗲𝗳𝗿𝗮𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗴 (Are we asking the right questions?)
 𝗜𝘁𝗲𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗮𝗱𝗮𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 (Are we willing to change our approach?)
 𝗕𝘂𝗶𝗹𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝘀𝗲𝗻𝘀𝘂𝘀 (Can we get buy-in and support?)

Without these steps, teams fall into 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗺𝗼𝗻 𝘁𝗿𝗮𝗽𝘀:

 Groupthink—where consensus outweighs critical thinking (Janis, 1972)
 Lack of structure—leading to indecision and frustration (The Wisdom of Crowds, Surowiecki)

 If you want to transform how your team makes decisions, check out my workshop:

“𝗙𝗿𝗼𝗺 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝘁𝗼 𝗦𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗴𝘆: 𝗗𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻-𝗠𝗮𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗧𝗿𝗮𝗻𝘀𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗺𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗱𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗵𝗶𝗽”



𝗕𝘆 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗲 𝗯𝗲𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗿 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝘁𝗲𝗮𝗺𝘀, 𝘄𝗲 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗮𝗰𝘁𝘂𝗮𝗹𝗹𝘆 𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗿𝗼𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗶𝘃𝗶𝗱𝘂𝗮𝗹 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗶𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻-𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘀𝗸𝗶𝗹𝗹𝘀.
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Team decision-making is indeed a different beast. Excited to explore these principles further in your workshop!

postsData.content:
Pitching is poison.

Well kinda.

I want you to pitch. I want you to make offers.

I. Want. You. To. Grow. Your. Business.

But a pitch before value is arsenic and old lace to your business.

You want a successful business, right?

You want it to last a long time and pay out for years, right?

Why you in such a hurry to give someone the ICK?

First, value.

Then, pitch.

Depth beats width.

The value make them wait a min more to listen to what you have to say through your pitch. The journey to the sale is more important than the sale itself

postsData.name:
Lucas Wilson
Lucas Wilson
postsData.content:
Pride Over Profit: The Real Measure of Success

Most people think businesses are built on equity, exits, and financial upside. But if that’s your only measure of success, you’ve already lost.

For those of us who wake up every day to serve customers, to solve real problems, to build something meaningful—pride is the real driver.

Pride in the businesses we help grow.
Pride in the team we lead.
Pride in the community we’ve built.

Signpost isn’t just another company to me—it’s a mission. A commitment. An obsession with getting it right for the SMBs who trust us to be their partner.

You can chase valuations and spreadsheets all day. But the real value? It’s in the work. The impact. The pride of knowing you built something great.

So ask yourself—why are you doing what you do? If your answer is only about financial gain, you’re missing the best part.
postsData.commentAdded: Well said! True success is rooted in pride and purpose. It’s inspiring to see organizations prioritize meaningful impact over mere profits. 🌟

postsData.name:
Laura Bolton
Laura Bolton
postsData.content:
If you experience feelings like stress, anger or frustration, the usual advice is to try and calm yourself with slow breathing or meditation.

But this NOT helpful.

These are “activated” states.

And if the energy isn't discharged it can cause us issues such as nervous system dysregulation, feeling crappy mentally/emotionally, limiting our access to our inner resources (such as creativity, critical thinking, problem solving, intuition).

And over time physical symptoms can manifest - for me it was experiencing a stroke and developing Fibromyalgia 3 years ago.

We cannot discharge this energy using the mind, which is why somatic techniques are so important.

We can also use them to release past trauma thats stored up in the body.

Once we’ve discharged the energy THEN we can do slow breathing to bring us back to a state of calm (if it feels required)

The forms of somatic release which work best for me are the TRE technique (Trauma Release Exercise) shaking it out, dancing and vocal release e.g singing, or screaming into a pillow when required lol.

How about you?

comments.commentText:
Great post. Feel the feelings. Have the courage to feel it all.

Screaming and growling, sometimes whilst running. Ideally in the forest.

Very slow nose breathing or the psychological sigh can bring me back also.

From my experience, confronting the fact my mind has not been willing to let it go is also a factor. I don’t see it as one or the other. It could be either or both

Brinsley Kazak yes! The willingness to feel (and not hold on) is important.

AND, different feelings/emotions require different techniques. When its an intense / activated energy, rather than sitting and feeling it, I shift it with movement (because just feeling it doesnt discharge it) Other less intense feelings may just require that we feel them. If we feel flat/depressed its best to use “activation” techniques. And so on
I just got a TRE state reading this post.

postsData.commentAdded: Thank you for sharing your insights! Its vital to address the body’s role in emotional health. What somatic techniques have you found most effective?

postsData.name:
Blessing Ikpia
Blessing Ikpia
postsData.content:
If you don't use the right words, you'll become INVISIBLE 

Meaning, you'd get zero attention 

and attention is currency in Marketing, so you'd be loosing money $$

A few days ago, I was deep into an SEO course when I had a lightbulb moment.

They kept emphasizing how keywords are the foundation of SEO, how the right words can determine whether your content gets discovered or buried under millions of search results.

And suddenly, it hit me.

SEO isn’t just about search engines. It’s exactly like marketing.

Think about it, marketing is all about understanding what people are looking for and POSITIONING your product, service, or brand as the solution. Just like SEO, if you’re speaking the wrong language (or using the wrong keywords), your audience won’t find you.

When I started marketing, I used to focus on what I wanted to say instead of what my audience was actively searching for.

But the moment I switched to addressing their pain points, answering their questions and using words they actually understood, engagement skyrocketed.

SEO works the same way. Google isn’t guessing—it's matching searches to the right content.

Your audience isn’t guessing either. They’re searching for solutions and if you’re not using the right “keywords” in your messaging, they won’t see you.

So my lesson for you today is:

 Whether you’re writing content

 Selling a product,

 or building a Brand

Speak the language of your audience. Research what they care about. Use their words. Align your message with their needs.

Because marketing without the right positioning is just like SEO without the right keywords, YOU'LL BE INVISIBLE 

Are you intentional about the words you use in your marketing?

Seeing me for the first time, I'm, a growth Marketer. I share my professional journey to empower young marketers. I also share resources like courses, mentorship programs and job vacancies to young professionals seeking global opportunities.

If this resonates with you, followfor more

postsData.name:
Duke Rem 🐢
Duke Rem 🐢
postsData.content:
A quote from 1973 that is more relevant today than ever:

 "We aren't dealing with ordinary machines here. These are highly complicated pieces of equipment. Almost as complicated as living organisms. In some cases, they have been designed by other computers. We don't know exactly how they work".

This was from the movie Westworld, written and directed by (the huge genious) Michael Crichton. 

In reflecting on today’s approach to AI, one cannot ignore the almost impenetrable nature of modern LLM training—a process that, despite its notable achievements, remains in many ways a black box.

These models are built through layers of deep learning whose inner mechanics "elude" even the experts. The training algorithms, fed with vast quantities of data, forge patterns and predictions with an efficiency that is both impressive and, at times, unsettling in its opacity.

It is instructive to consider the implications if one were to transplant such an LLM into a robotic body—a “corpus” capable of interacting with the physical world.

In this scenario, the limitations and strengths of these systems would be put to a new test: the model would have to contend with the tangible, unpredictable nature of reality. This would require not only the capacity for abstract reasoning but also an understanding of cause and effect in a dynamic environment.

How might such a system reconcile the rigor of its internal algorithms with the messy, ever-changing tapestry of the real world?

And what safeguards must be put in place to ensure that its decision-making remains transparent and accountable?

 Please upvote and share this post. We need your support to give you the best magazine focused on news and insights in the AI world. ⬇️
postsData.commentAdded: This quote is a powerful reminder of the complexities we face with AI today. Excited to see how we can bridge the gap between algorithms and reality!

postsData.name:
Amelia Sordell 🔥
Amelia Sordell 🔥
postsData.content:
If you Google my name, about 35,300 results come up.

That’s not an accident. It’s by design.

Most people think personal branding is just posting content.

It’s not.

It’s about making sure you exist in the places that matter - and are seen by the people that matter.

People Google you before they meet you.

- Employers Google you before they hire you.
- Clients Google you before they buy from you.
- Dates Google you before they go out with you.
- Heck, you’ve Googled yourself (don't lie, we all have ).

So here’s a ridiculously simple hack that’s been working for me for years:

Personal branding, speaking, being an author and entrepreneur is what I want to be known for. And so, every time I upload an image or video, I save the file in one of the following format:

“[MY NAME] - [WHAT I WANT TO BE KNOWN FOR] [INSERT NAME OF POST]”

For example:

"Amelia Sordell - Personal Branding - Google Your Name”

Why? Because Google reads file names.
Because SEO isn’t just for websites.
Because visibility isn’t luck—it’s strategy.

Most people are waiting to be discovered - I make sure I can’t be ignored.

Your name should be your business card and if you want more from life, your digital footprint should speak before you do.

If you're at the beginning of that journey, a good place to start is here:

Make yourself Googleable or leave your visibility to chance.

I know which one I choose - how about you?!

comments.commentText: It's not okay to just post, you have to make yourself visible too Amelia Sordell

postsData.name:
Michał Choiński
Michał Choiński
postsData.content:
The real cost of inefficient workflows 

Many organizations focus on growth, innovation, and customer experience, but overlook a silent killer of progress: inefficient workflows.
The hidden costs:

→ Wasted time on unnecessary approvals and redundant processes
→Teams working in silos, leading to misalignment and rework
→ Low morale when talented employees are stuck in bureaucratic inefficiencies

Transformational leaders don’t just optimize. They inspire change.

Instead of chasing short-term efficiency gains, they:
️ Empower teams to rethink and improve their workflows proactively
️ Foster a culture of ownership where employees identify and fix inefficiencies
️ Align processes with purpose, ensuring every workflow drives meaningful impact

Where to Start?

→Challenge the “we’ve always done it this way” mindset
→Encourage open discussions on pain points and process improvements
→Lead by example, remove obstacles, not just manage around them

True transformation isn’t about doing things faster, it’s about working smarter and enabling teams to thrive.

At Mchange, we help organizations identify, streamline, and transform inefficient workflows to drive sustainable success.

 Ready to rethink your processes? DM me or book a free strategy call in our website.

comments.commentText: Nerea Arregui Exposito thank you !

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely spot on! Transforming workflows is crucial for unlocking potential. Excited to see leaders embrace this change! #WorkplaceTransformation

postsData.content:
TIME’S ALMOST UP – 3 DAYS LEFT TO APPLY! 

Alright, AI & automation fam—this is NOT a drill. postsData.name:
Adam Robinson
Adam Robinson
postsData.content:
We closed January at $25.3m ARR (+.8%). RB2B was up 9% at $4.5m ARR and Retention.com was down 1% at $20.8m ARR. Here’s what went well (and not so well) last month:

What went well:

1. Despite cutting all marketing expense in Dec ($100k/mo), RB2B grew 9%
2. First true enterprise deal closed on Dec 31 at Retention!
3. We're making progress on our “run the signal through CRM” hypothesis at RB2B, SFDC integration finishes this week
4. Forming a VERY strong partnership w/ Bloomreach at R!
5.planned what will be an amazing full-team offsite next week
6. We substantially improved our identity at RB2B - much higher coverage
7. We are SOC2 Type II Compliant (and I need to add it to our websites)
8.thinks we had our best Live Event (with Clay) last week - I agree
9. We generated $1,112,904 of free cash (profit) in January

What went NOT so well:

1. Everybody in ecomm who is going to cancel does so after the holidays
2. RB2B product is nowhere close to where we want it to be (but it will be)
3. I am very confused about how to look at attribution with RB2B

TAKEAWAY:

We shrunk 2.5% in Q124, but ended up growing 15% y-o-y.

We also shrunk in Q121 and Q122.

(The only reason we didn’t in Q123 is we were having an out-of-body product-market fit experience that has since subsided)

I think Q1 is a hard quarter for anybody selling to ecommerce.

Thankfully, somehow, RB2B came to the rescue this January.

But here’s the crazy thing…

For the life of me, I can’t understand WHY it came to the rescue.

I declared RB2B dead on Nov 21, and between then and Jan 1 we got so absolutely slaughtered by churn that we didn’t grow at all.

I also chopped all of our marketing expense, because my view was we were burning leads bringing people on to a product that wasn’t ready yet.

What happened?

Up 9% month-over-month.

To $4.5m ARR.

For the life of me I can’t explain how or why that happened.

But here I am - once again - saying I cut spend and growth sped up.

Just like in mid-2023, when I cut our BDR org.

Maybe the Startup Gods just wants to send me a message.

The most valuable message a founder could ever hear.

What’s that message?

“Get smaller… and thank me later.”

P.S.

I started a newsletter. Join 40,000+ subscribers as I share everything about growing my third SaaS startup to $10m ARR.

comments.commentText:
Cyclicality.

B2B Buyers on the Traditional Fiscal calendar Jan - Dec.
Ecom Buyers on the Lunar cycle: March - Feb.

Budget refreshes are beautiful and Brands don't buy after seeing an ad for 1 month.

postsData.commentAdded: Incredible resilience despite challenges! It’s fascinating how strategic cuts can lead to unexpected growth. Excited to see where RB2B heads next!

postsData.name:
Christina Langdon - Success Coach
Christina Langdon - Success Coach
postsData.content:
Everyone is 100% committed.
You can tell what you're committed to by the results you are producing.

This quote revealed something I’ve been dancing around for years:

I wasn't lacking commitment – I was committed to the wrong things.

As a high performer, I wore my exhaustion like a badge of honor some days. Three-hour daily commutes, back-to-back meetings, multitasking through conversations that deserved full attention.

These weren't signs of dedication; they were evidence of my commitment to chaos.

I was perfectly successful on paper and perfectly miserable in reality.
While grinding away at my publishing career, I wasn't committed to impact or growth. I worked with a Coach to help me see it.

It was costing me time, money, exhaustion, and joy.

I was committed to being busy, to being productive, to my performance of "doing more than most."

I collected promotions and achievements, but they felt hollow because they weren't aligned with what I truly wanted to create in the world.

I hear the same themes echoing in my leadership workshops and from my 1:1 clients:
"I don't have enough time,"
"I'm at capacity,"
"I can't see another way."

Here's what I've learned – these aren't capacity issues; they're commitment issues.

We're all operating at 100% commitment; we're just not always conscious of what we're committed to.

As 2025 unfolds, I'm making a radical change. Not by working harder and doing more but by becoming the caretaker of my energy.

I'm committed to this year looking different from the last. Are you?

Not through increased activity but through crystal-clear intention.
Without this clarity, I risk living the same year on repeat. How about you?

Alex Hormozi, entrepreneur and investor (a bit whacky and super smart), defines success not by what he achieves but by the quality and quantity of his "nos."

Clear commitment isn't about adding more; it's about choosing better.

Recognize that every "yes" is also a commitment to our most precious resource: our energy.

You're already 100% committed. The question is: to what?

#2025
____________________________________

Working with a Coach changed my life.

It helped me get off the hamster wheel, working on default each day. It's why I became a Coach. My operational experience, matched with my Human A-I Coaching curriculum, delivers exceptional results for my high-achieving clients who want freedom, ease, and impact.

DM me for a chemistry call.
postsData.commentAdded: Powerful insights! Its so true that alignment with our true values leads to real success. Excited to hear how 2025 unfolds for you! 🌟

postsData.name:
Sonia Hunt
Sonia Hunt
postsData.content:
𝟱 𝗧𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴𝘀 𝗜'𝘃𝗲 𝗟𝗲𝗮𝗿𝗻𝗲𝗱 𝗔𝗯𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝗗𝗲𝗲𝗽𝗦𝗲𝗲𝗸 & 𝗔𝗜’𝘀 𝗙𝘂𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲:


1. 𝗟𝗟𝗠𝘀 𝗪𝗶𝗹𝗹 𝗕𝗲𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗮 𝗖𝗼𝗺𝗺𝗼𝗱𝗶𝘁𝘆
-You don’t need to be a billion-dollar company to build an LLM.
-While models differ slightly, they largely function the same.
-The real differentiator is how you fine-tune and apply them.

2. 𝗛𝘆𝗽𝗲 ≠ 𝗕𝘂𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗜𝗺𝗽𝗮𝗰𝘁
-The best AI model for your business depends on your use case.
-Experiment internally first—roll it out to employees.
-Test responses, Track the data, and Tweak before scaling.

3. 𝗕𝘂𝗶𝗹𝗱 𝘃𝘀. 𝗛𝗼𝘀𝘁: 𝗖𝗵𝗼𝗼𝘀𝗲 𝗪𝗶𝘀𝗲𝗹𝘆
-Keeping AI models in-house requires major $$$$$.
-Opt for a hybrid approach, leveraging other GPTs or renting GPUs to test before committing.
-Security, governance, and ROI should drive decisions.

4. 𝗔𝗜 𝗔𝗴𝗲𝗻𝘁𝘀 𝗔𝗿𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗡𝗲𝘅𝘁 𝗕𝗶𝗴 𝗕𝗲𝘁
-VCs are pouring money into AI agents.
-These tools automate repetitive processes and trigger actions instantly.
-The key is to keep them tuned as business needs evolve.

5. 𝗪𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗻’𝘀 𝗩𝗼𝗶𝗰𝗲𝘀 𝗔𝗿𝗲 𝗡𝗲𝗲𝗱𝗲𝗱 𝗶𝗻 𝗔𝗜
-AI is shaping the future, yet conversations often lack diverse perspectives.
-We need more women at the forefront of these discussions—on stage and in leadership.

AI is a journey, not a one-time implementation.

Be intentional, start with a project, and continuously refine your approach.

Many thanks toandfor an interesting discussion on 'Microsoft & DeepSeek - What to Know.'

Where do you see AI making the biggest impact in your business?
postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! The emphasis on womens voices in AI is crucial for innovation. Continuous refinement is key to harnessing AIs potential!

postsData.name:
Craig T. Ingram
Craig T. Ingram
postsData.content:
One week challenge: Go to your business coach (that you’re paying), and ask that person if they see you settling too often for mediocrity. 

Being a high achiever is lonely. I have to admit… That I have been lonely many times throughout my career, because my standard is extremely high.

My level of expectation of myself in being able to perform in the business world at an elite level keeps me in a mode of continuous learning and being coached by ultra high level serial entrepreneurs.

Business is hard! And the only way to stay at a level of high-performance is accountability and not settling for mediocrity.

93.4% of businesses never achieve $1 million in annual revenue.

But if you are a person who has individually grew a business from zero dollars to $1 million in revenue, you are more effective than 93.3% of the people on planet Earth doing business.
postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! Embracing accountability and striving for excellence is key. Lets push past mediocrity together and redefine success! 💪🚀

postsData.name:
Andre Gaubert
Andre Gaubert
postsData.content:
This January, I have had the misfortune of being sick for two out of the past four weekends. During the Minnesota winter, it's pretty common for illness like the flu, colds, and other viruses to start spreading around due to more people being indoors and exposure to cold weather

During my times being sick however, I often am reminded of the importance of rest and taking care of oneself. As someone who tends to be constantly moving at times, slowing down and resting can be challenging.

As a data/ technology professional working in data consulting, there is a constant drive to generate the best possible product/results for the clients we work with.

With how detail-oriented, solution-driven, and analytical minded data professionals need to be in order to succeed, it's easy to forget how much that drive can wear us out and mentally exhaust us.

It's important therefore, to give yourself breaks and rest when you know you're worn out (sick or not), and have time to rest, so that way, you have the energy and attention to drive solid data drive results when the time is the perform.

At the end of the day, there is always performance element to delivering solid data driven solutions.

Like most performers in general, it's hard to perform your best when you know you aren't at your best.

Take care of yourself this Q1 everyone!
postsData.commentAdded: Thank you for sharing this important reminder! Balancing drive with self-care is essential for long-term success in any field. Get well soon!

postsData.name:
Parker Ence
Parker Ence
postsData.content:
Big news at Jump - Advisor AI today: we closed a $20M series A round led by Battery Ventures, with Citi Ventures, Sorenson Capital, and Pelion Venture Partners!

I love working with our customers and I feel grateful every day that we can support them in some small way as they help more than a third of the population navigate some of the most important decisions of their lives. This funding round means we can continue to build even faster - more AI tools for advisors that help them put on the "ironman suit" towards our mission to empower advisors and their customers to thrive in the age of AI!

Going from 1 customer to thousands of customers, from 3 cofounders to over 50 team members, and launching partnerships with wonderful technology companies and leading advisor networks all in the last 365 days has been the ride of a lifetime. I am so happy to share this journey with Jump cofoundersandas well as,,, and the rest of our INCREDIBLE Jump team. (We are hiring for many new roles - check them out at!)

We are excited thatfrom Battery Ventures is leading our Series A - he brings extremely relevant experience from his time as an early investor and long time board member of Gong as well as with dozens of other successful companies such as Databricks. We are also excited to welcome Citi Ventures as Jump investors - they bring great industry perspective and connections. They join our existing investorsandat Sorenson andand team at Pelion who are incredible partners, andwho backed us pre-idea.

Some companies raise big VC checks and then set that money on fire, wasting it quickly on their way to bankruptcy. That’s not our style—we have been close to cash flow positive this year and raised this round not because we were almost out of our seed money but because we wanted to move even faster to meet the demand for great advisor AI tools.

Today, our customers tell us that they save an average of 1-2 hours per workday with Jump's meeting assistant, and in some cases, have increased client service deliverables by 20-50% per advisor. Jump has developed a reputation for providing category defining advisor-specific workflows, integrations, and customization options, while enabling enterprise compliance teams with lots of options and a path to sign off on safe AI deployment in a highly regulated space. Expect to see lots more from Jump in each of these areas, plus plenty of new things this year as we build ever faster...

If you are an advisor or are otherwise in financial services, please check us out at- our team would love to meet you!

comments.commentText: Congrats!!

postsData.commentAdded: Congratulations to the entire Jump team on this milestone! Excited to see how this funding will accelerate innovation in advisor AI tools! 🚀

postsData.name:
Meredith Sims, ChFC®, CSRIC®
Meredith Sims, ChFC®, CSRIC®
postsData.content:
When you hear "net worth," you probably think about money—what’s in your bank account, what you own, what you owe. And yes, that’s important. It gives you a big-picture view of your finances, something I often find missing when I first talk to clients.

But real wealth? That goes beyond dollars and cents.

What about your skills and talents? Your experiences, health, relationships? And a big one for me—your time. Time to explore, to travel, to enjoy life on your terms.

So yes, track your financial net worth. Just don’t let it define your full value. Because when you step back, your true worth is so much more.

comments.commentText: True wealth isn’t just about money; it’s the value of your time, relationships, and experiences that truly define a fulfilling life.

postsData.commentAdded: Absolutely! True wealth encompasses our skills, relationships, and time. Its vital to see the bigger picture beyond just finances! 🔑✨

postsData.name:
Luigi LENGUITO
Luigi LENGUITO
postsData.content:
Adversary are creating AI-twins scraping information about each of us from social media and other online sources. Phishing will become ever more credible as the tone, information and requests will be spectacularly tuned.

A few items to consider :
- ACM - Always Change Medium : never follow-up answering a message , switch to a different media of random choice (email -> phone, phone -> whatsapp, whatsapp -> slack, slack -> text,etc.)
- Identity Keyword - agree with your close circle an individually dedicated special word, something that is not in the ether/media - but is memorable, to be used to validate identity
- Verify, then trust : lower the level of trust you put in online media, always look for alternative sources before accepting an information as true.

comments.commentText: Phishing's evolving from "Dear Sir/Madam, urgent assistance required" to eerily accurate imitations of real people. A deepfake voice here, a cloned writing style there—suddenly, your boss is "totally" asking you to wire money to an offshore account. Brave new world, indeed :P
Zsolt N. impersonation risk started with Adam and Eve, just saying....
Luigi LENGUITO Serpent convinces Eve, Eve convinces Adam, and boom, unauthorized access to the Tree of Knowledge. Classic phishing scam. :P

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Staying vigilant and adapting our communication methods is crucial in this evolving digital landscape. Trust must be earned!

postsData.name:
Inc Tank GTM
Inc Tank GTM
postsData.content:
Welcome to the Flagship Edition of The Inkubator Dispatch – Where Tech Meets Hospitality (and Your Bottom Line)

 Friends, Technologists Operators, Tech Skeptics—Lend Me Your Clicks!
This is not your average, feel-good, “let’s talk about industry trends” newsletter. Nope. This is a flashlight in the haunted house of hospitality tech—where every new SaaS subscription comes with promises of profit but often just eats into it instead.

We’re here to talk about the real numbers, the real headaches, and the real future of hospitality tech—minus the fluff. If you’ve ever looked at your tech stack and thought:

 "Why do I have 14 different subscriptions to run a single restaurant?"
 "Wait… am I actually making money on this stuff?"
 "If one more vendor says ‘game-changer,’ I’m throwing my POS out the window."

Then, welcome home!

This flagship edition of The Inkubator Dispatch kicks off with SaaS-Quatch: The Mythical ROI of Hospitality Tech—a deep dive into the growing monster of SaaS fatigue, how much it's really costing you, and what the future looks like as operators start pushing back.

Why should you care? Because if you’re in the business of selling food, running hotels, or keeping the lights on in hospitality, the tech you choose directly impacts your profitability. We’re here to help you cut through the noise, call out the BS, and highlight the solutions that actually work.

 Buckle up—The Inkubator Dispatch is fast, fun, and dangerously honest. And if we do our job right? You might just make (and keep) more money.
Now, let’s get into it.

Read the first edition here!

comments.commentText: And don't forget that the SaaS takes up management time to config and operate... a cost on top of SaaS and some of the UI/uX was designed during the horse and buggy days, really hard to operate so people tend to give up. AI operators are going to clean some clocks in the market.

postsData.name:
Sam Jacobs
Sam Jacobs
postsData.content:
14 things every CMO needs to know to do their job and not get fired:

1. You are a storyteller. You know this but it bears repeating. Because storytelling is the essential skill of every modern executive. You have to be good at it.

2. You need to find some way to allocate some budget to brand, even if your CEO doesn’t understand why.

3. For most B2B tech, brand is the only long term moat.

4. You’ve got to think like a hedge fund manager. Your investments are fungible across people and programs. Your goal is high growth at low CAC and it’s up to you how to do that. Which is really f-ing hard.

5. Nobody gives a sh*t about leads. You deliver qualified pipeline and closed business. The days of the MQL are over. Don’t even say that word out loud in a modern tech org.

6.is wrong about a lot. Like … A LOT. But one thing he’s right about: dark social is real. If you don’t have a strategy for communities, you are NOT where your customers are sharing their honest opinion.

7. Great brands build trust. But they build trust because they have personality. If your marketing has no personality - authentic personality, not cringey Hail Mary attempts - you don’t have a chance.

8. AI is not a strategy. It’s a tool. You use it. But you do need to use it. And to do that you need to know what’s going on. Have you heard of? Of?? If not, you’re behind.

9. Sales people don’t generate demand. You do. You have the hardest job in the company.

10. So if your CEO doesn’t truly “get” marketing, you can try convincing them, but it’s a big red flag. Great marketing wins ball games. And is rare.

11. You have to live in numbers. You just do. You have to build our own models (or know how to). You have to use spreadsheets.

12. You have to know how to read a P&L. You have to understand, just like the CRO, what makes companies great and what makes companies crap and you have to be able to get to that answer through numbers.

13. You set the standard. Brands are built with precision. If you let mediocrity walk into your materials, your copy, your aesthetic - that’s what the company becomes. Be careful and focus on the details.

14. Marketing is the hardest discipline. It just is. It’s an alchemic mix of art and science, of making big bets and fine-tuning the numbers, of motivating teams of creatives and telling stories to the CEO. It’s really really hard.

We want you to become a great CMO.

I want you to become a great CMO.

And part of that journey is joiningfor CMO School, led by my friend, and now featuring an incredible array of CMO instructors now including.

CMO School starts TOMORROW.

DM me to join us.

comments.commentText:
There's some irony in my thoughts about Brand.

I had a great discussion with my CEO yesterday about why our Brand needs a personality....at least in principle.

We both agreed that for high ACV plays, Brand Awareness is a must have, cause no one's gonna buy from you if they don't know you.

But where we both stopped short is whenasked said "Ok, a persona sounds great, but what does it actually mean, how do we codify this, and why is it so important?"

I listed off of a few examples of cool B2B brands and my perceived assessment of their "Persona".

But I was equally stumped.

We've seen the success of "Individual"-driven brand > Corporate in B2B (ex:,,)

Why should we prioritize Company Brand Persona as opposed to building up our individual brands?

This post got me excited, thinking it might have some answers.

But I find myself no less lost than I was, yesterday.

That said, when we talking allocating budget to Brand, does this course offer the answer to my question, "What for?"

postsData.commentAdded: This is a fantastic roadmap for aspiring CMOs! Embracing storytelling and data-driven strategies is crucial. Excited for CMO School! 🚀

postsData.name:
Simran Pant
Simran Pant
postsData.content:
Is your LinkedIn headline letting you down?

Here are the top 10 mistakes to avoid.

I’ve drafted 100+ LinkedIn headlines to learn what works.

You have 45 characters to make a first impression. Don't waste them.

Avoid these headline mistakes now↓

1. Using a generic job title
2. Ignoring the 45-character limit
3. Not communicating value
4. Failing to use a hook
5. Being too vague
6. Not using keywords
7. Focusing on your own wins, not on your client's
8. Not updating regularly
9. Forgetting the rehook
10. Not treating your profile as a conversation starter

Use your headline to clearly show how you help others.

Say what you do and who you do it for.

P.S. Which mistake surprised you the most (1-10)? What would you add?

comments.commentText: I think the most surprising mistake is number 7. It's important to focus on how we can help our clients rather than just showcasing our own accomplishments.

postsData.commentAdded: Great tips! It’s amazing how a strong headline can transform your profile. Mistake #3—communicating value—resonates with me. What else can we add?

postsData.name:
Dennis Olympios

postsData.content:
Want to know why you should start mimicking successful strategies like a parrot? (It's the secret to sustainable growth!)

The Parrot Effect is more than just mimicry; it’s about leveraging repetition for success.

In business, sticking to effective strategies and repeating them until they become second nature can be incredibly powerful.

 Repetition Builds Mastery: Practice leads to proficiency, embedding successful habits into your routine.

 Consistency Creates Trust: Reliable excellence strengthens your reputation with clients and team members.

 Foundation for Innovation: Once the basics are solid, you’re free to innovate without losing your footing.

Embrace repetition as your secret weapon.

What strategies do you consistently hone? Share your thoughts!

comments.commentText: I love how you emphasize the power of repetition! By repeating effective strategies, we not only gain proficiency but also create a foundation to innovate. Once our basics are locked down, we can take risks and improve without losing our grip on what’s working.

postsData.commentAdded: Great insights! Embracing the Parrot Effect can truly elevate both personal and team growth. Im all about honing effective strategies consistently! 🦜✨

postsData.name:
Priyank Ahuja
Priyank Ahuja
postsData.content:
𝗧𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗿𝗲𝘀𝘂𝗺𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘀 𝗮𝗻 𝗔𝗧𝗦 𝘀𝗰𝗼𝗿𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝟵𝟱!

I’m sharing detailed step-by-step resume building techniques that helps you to land your dream job.

I am breaking it down below, with the help of different colors

𝐑𝐞𝐝 = 𝐀𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐕𝐞𝐫𝐛𝐬:
We start each experience with an action verb; if it’s in a current position, you can put as present and if past, you put as -Ed (Example of great action verbs: Collaborated, managed, improved)

𝐏𝐢𝐧𝐤 = 𝐇𝐚𝐫𝐝 𝐒𝐤𝐢𝐥𝐥𝐬:
We put the specific hard skills and platform-based skills throughout resume to show that you fit the job description's qualifications; at the bottom, you also have the skills and match them to your experiences where applicable which you can do for your own resume. (Example: I was going into Strategy/Operations, so I put relevant skills pertaining to the industry)

𝐍𝐨𝐭 𝐜𝐨𝐥𝐨𝐫𝐞𝐝, 𝐛𝐮𝐭 𝐚𝐭 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐭𝐨𝐩 = 𝐄𝐝𝐮𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧:
Put where you graduated, GPA if over a 3.5, organizations/awards, etc. IMO Relevant coursework is optional; you can add this if you don't have relevant experience (yet) or are working on gaining those experiences.

𝐇𝐞𝐚𝐝𝐞𝐫:
Location as (City, State), LinkedIn (linked), phone number and email (Optional: Portfolio/Personal Website).

𝐆𝐫𝐞𝐞𝐧 = 𝐈𝐦𝐩𝐚𝐜𝐭 𝐌𝐞𝐭𝐫𝐢𝐜𝐬:
These are numbers and percentages from the positions you worked in and showcase what you did to impact the company. How did you get these numbers through a) asking your peers/managers b) calculated estimations based on observations?

𝐂𝐲𝐚𝐧 = 𝐈𝐦𝐩𝐚𝐜𝐭 𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 𝐛𝐞𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐧𝐮𝐦𝐛𝐞𝐫/𝐩𝐞𝐫𝐜𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐚𝐠𝐞𝐬:
This showcases if you improved, optimized or increased xyz which is related to Operations role lingo.

𝐘𝐞𝐥𝐥𝐨𝐰 = 𝐒𝐨𝐟𝐭 𝐒𝐤𝐢𝐥𝐥𝐬:
More broad or simple statements, these are relative to collaboration, providing recommendations, and identifying solutions to potential problems.

Note:
Education at the top if a student/new grad, move to bottom after experiences once early in career/professional.

Follow

Like, Comment, Share for better reach.

Book your 1:1 session at:

Twitter:

Threads:
Telegram:

Please turn the 𝗯𝗲𝗹𝗹 "" 𝗶𝗰𝗼𝗻 on my profile, if you don't want to miss any of my content related to "𝘾𝙖𝙧𝙚𝙚𝙧 𝙂𝙪𝙞𝙙𝙖𝙣𝙘𝙚, 𝙄𝙣𝙩𝙚𝙧𝙫𝙞𝙚𝙬 𝙋𝙧𝙚𝙥𝙖𝙧𝙖𝙩𝙞𝙤𝙣, 𝙋𝙚𝙧𝙨𝙤𝙣𝙖𝙡 𝙁𝙞𝙣𝙖𝙣𝙘𝙚, 𝙋𝙧𝙤𝙙𝙪𝙘𝙩 𝙈𝙖𝙣𝙖𝙜𝙚𝙢𝙚𝙣𝙩 and 𝙈𝙖𝙣𝙖𝙜𝙚𝙢𝙚𝙣𝙩 𝘾𝙤𝙣𝙨𝙪𝙡𝙩𝙞𝙣𝙜"
